answer_html: \(\displaystyle -a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3(2a_{1} + b_{1})=-5a_{1}.\) From this we get that \(c_{1} = 2a_{1} - 5a_{1} = -3a_{1}\).Thus, any vector of the form k[1,-5,-3] where k is a constant (not equal to zero) will be parallel to L.For example, the vectors [1,-5,-3] and [-2,10,6] are acceptable solutions.

$\displaystyle
-a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3(2a_{1} + b_{1})=-5a_{1}.$ 
From this we get that $c_{1} = 2a_{1} - 5a_{1} = -3a_{1}$.Thus, any vector of the form k{[}1,-5,-3{]} where k is a constant (not

{[}1,-5,-3{]} and {[}-2,10,6{]} are acceptable solutions.
hints_html:
For any vector \(\mathbf{u}\), The line \(\mathbf{u} + t\mathbf{v}\), \(t \in \mathbb{R}\) is parallel to the vector \(\mathbf{v}\).

If a vector, v, is parallel to a plane P, then v is perpendicular to the normal vector of P.

If two vectors are perpendicular, what is the dot product between them equal to?
hints_latex:
For any vector $\mathbf{u}$, The line $\mathbf{u} + t\mathbf{v}$,
$t \in \mathbb{R}$ is parallel to the vector $\mathbf{v}$.

If a vector, v, is parallel to a plane P, then v is perpendicular to the
normal vector of P.

If two vectors are perpendicular, what is the dot product between them
equal to?
hints_raw:
For any vector <math>\mathbf{u}</math>, The line <math>\mathbf{u} + t\mathbf{v}</math>, <math>t \in \mathbb{R}</math> is parallel to the vector <math>\mathbf{v}</math>.
If a vector, <b>v</b>, is parallel to a plane <b>P</b>, then <b>v</b> is perpendicular to the normal vector of <b>P</b>. 

If two vectors are perpendicular, what is the dot product between them equal to?
question: 1 (a)
sols_html:
Let the line L be written in vector form as

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle [a_{0},b_{0},c_{0}] + [a_{1},b_{1},b_{2}]t.\end{aligned}\]

If L is parallel to the plane 2x + y - z = 5, then L must be perpendicular to the normal vector of said plane, n = [2,1,-1]. i.e. The dot product between n and the direction of L must be equal to zero:

\[\begin{aligned} [2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 0.\end{aligned}\]

Evaluating the dot product gives:

\[\begin{aligned} \mathbf{(1)} \quad [2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 2a_{1} + b_{1} - c_{1} = 0\end{aligned}\]

Remember that we also need the vector is perpendicular to the line,\([3 - t, 1 - 2t, 3t] = [3,1,0] + [-1,-2,3]t.\) Hence, the following equation must also be satisfied:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \mathbf{(2)} \quad [-1,-2,3] \cdot [a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = -a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3c_{1} = 0\end{aligned}\]

So we have two equations and three unknowns. This means there are infinitely many vectors that will satisfy the given conditions. We only need to find one. (Note: Clearly \(a_{1} = b_{1} = c_{1} = 0\) is a solution to the above equations (1), (2), but it is the trivial solution and is perpendicular to every vector, including the direction of the line L.)

Solving (1) for \(c_{1}\) gives \(c_{1} = 2a_{1} + b_{1}\). Subbing this into (2) gives

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle -a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3(2a_{1} + b_{1}) = 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad b_{1} = -5a_{1}.\end{aligned}\]

From this we get that \(c_{1} = 2a_{1} - 5a_{1} = -3a_{1}\).

Thus, any vector of the form k[1,-5,-3] where k is a constant (not equal to zero) will be parallel to L. For example, the vectors [1,-5,-3] and [-2,10,6] are acceptable solutions.
sols_latex:
Let the line L be written in vector form as

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
[a_{0},b_{0},c_{0}] + [a_{1},b_{1},b_{2}]t.
\end{align*} If L is parallel to the
plane 2x + y - z = 5, then L must be perpendicular to the normal vector
of said plane, n = {[}2,1,-1{]}. i.e. The dot product between n and the
direction of L must be equal to zero:

\begin{align*}
[2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 0.
\end{align*} Evaluating the dot product
gives:

\begin{align*}
\mathbf{(1)} \quad [2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 2a_{1} + b_{1} - c_{1} = 0
\end{align*}
Remember that we also need the vector is perpendicular to the
line,$[3 - t, 1 - 2t, 3t] = [3,1,0] + [-1,-2,3]t.$ Hence, the following
equation must also be satisfied:

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
\mathbf{(2)} \quad [-1,-2,3] \cdot [a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = -a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3c_{1} = 0
\end{align*}
So we have two equations and three unknowns. This means there are
infinitely many vectors that will satisfy the given conditions. We only
need to find one. (Note: Clearly $a_{1} = b_{1} = c_{1} = 0$ is a
solution to the above equations (1), (2), but it is the trivial solution
and is perpendicular to every vector, including the direction of the
line L.)

Solving (1) for $c_{1}$ gives $c_{1} = 2a_{1} + b_{1}$. Subbing this
into (2) gives

\begin{align*}
\displaystyle
-a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3(2a_{1} + b_{1}) = 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad b_{1} = -5a_{1}.
\end{align*}
From this we get that $c_{1} = 2a_{1} - 5a_{1} = -3a_{1}$.

Thus, any vector of the form k{[}1,-5,-3{]} where k is a constant (not
equal to zero) will be parallel to L. For example, the vectors
{[}1,-5,-3{]} and {[}-2,10,6{]} are acceptable solutions.
sols_raw:
Let the line <i>L</i> be written in vector form as 
:<math> \displaystyle
[a_{0},b_{0},c_{0}] + [a_{1},b_{1},b_{2}]t.
</math>
If <i>L</i> is parallel to the plane <i>2x + y - z = 5</i>, then <i>L</i> must be perpendicular to the normal vector of said plane, <b>n</b> = [2,1,-1]. i.e. The dot product between <b>n</b> and the direction of <i>L</i> must be equal to zero:
:<math>
[2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 0.
</math>
Evaluating the dot product gives:
:<math>
\mathbf{(1)} \quad [2,1,-1]\cdot[a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = 2a_{1} + b_{1} - c_{1} = 0
</math>
Remember that we also need the vector is perpendicular to the line,<math> [3 - t, 1 - 2t, 3t] = [3,1,0] + [-1,-2,3]t.</math>
Hence, the following equation must also be satisfied:
:<math> \displaystyle
\mathbf{(2)} \quad [-1,-2,3] \cdot [a_{1},b_{1},c_{1}] = -a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3c_{1} = 0
</math>
So we have two equations and three unknowns. This means there are infinitely many vectors that will satisfy the given conditions. We only need to find one. (<b>Note</b>: Clearly <math>a_{1} = b_{1} = c_{1} = 0</math> is a solution to the above equations (1), (2), but it is the trivial solution and is perpendicular to every vector, including the direction of the line <i>L</i>.)

Solving <b>(1)</b> for <math>c_{1}</math> gives <math>c_{1} = 2a_{1} + b_{1}</math>. Subbing this into <b>(2)</b> gives
:<math>\displaystyle
-a_{1} - 2b_{1} + 3(2a_{1} + b_{1}) = 0 \quad \rightarrow \quad b_{1} = -5a_{1}.
</math>
From this we get that <math>c_{1} = 2a_{1} - 5a_{1} = -3a_{1}</math>. 

<font style="color:blue">Thus, any vector of the form <i>k[1,-5,-3]</i> where <i>k</i> is a constant (not equal to zero) will be parallel to <i>L</i>. For example, the vectors <i>[1,-5,-3]</i> and <i>[-2,10,6]</i> are acceptable solutions</font>.
statement_html:
Let L be the line which is parallel to the plane

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle{}2x+y-z=5\end{aligned}\]

and perpendicular to the line

\[\begin{aligned} x=3-t\qquad{}y=1-2t\qquad{}z=3t.\end{aligned}\]

Find a vector parallel to the line L.
statement_raw:
Let ''L'' be the line which is parallel to the plane

:<math>
\displaystyle{}2x+y-z=5
</math>

and perpendicular to the line

:<math>
x=3-t\qquad{}y=1-2t\qquad{}z=3t.
</math>

Find a vector parallel to the line ''L''.
